1.title: Support the Equal Justice Initiative
1.subtitle: Your contribution is critical to efforts to end mass incarceration and excessive punishment in the United States, challenge racial and economic injustice, and protect the basic human rights for the most vulnerable people in American society.

1.title: Why Protests and Riots Work
1.subtitle: Riots are destructive, dangerous, and scary — but can lead to serious social reforms. To prevent more violent uprisings and protests, we need to take their causes seriously.

2.title: Revisionist History: Miss Buchanan’s Period of Adjustment
2.subtitle: Revisionist History is a podcast from Malcolm Gladwell and Pushkin Industries.In this episode: A landmark Supreme Court case. A civil rights revolution. Why has everyone forgotten what happened next?

2.title: What Happened on May 25th?
2.subtitle: On May 25th, 2020, George Floyd was in Minneapolis on business, far from his family and community, when four Minneapolis police officers murdered him in broad daylight. It was a modern day lynching as those police officers served as judge, jury, and executioner on an unarmed, non-violent, handcuffed Black man.

3.title: MoonXCosmetics
3.subtitle: Handmade vegan skincare for all skin types.

3.title: Liberation Library
3.subtitle: Young people in the jails and prisons we serve are experiencing a loss of programming and in-person family visits, leading to further isolation during these uncertain times. We believe it is now more important than ever for incarcerated young people to have access to other worlds of their choosing.

4.title: Did you really just say that?
4.subtitle: Here's advice on how to confront microaggressions, whether you're a target, bystander or perpetrator

4.title: Not all Black people are African American. Here's the difference.
4.subtitle: Black Lives Matter protests have opened up conversations about the history of privilege, racism, and the lived experiences and identities of black people in America. Now, the distinction between "Black" and "African American" has become a prominent conversation on social media.

5.title: NAACP Legal Defense and Education Fund
5.subtitle: Through litigation, advocacy, and public education, LDF seeks structural changes to expand democracy, eliminate disparities, and achieve racial justice in a society that fulfills the promise of equality for all Americans. LDF also defends the gains and protections won over the past 75 years of civil rights struggle and works to improve the quality and diversity of judicial and executive appointments.

5.title: The Case for Reparations
5.subtitle: Two hundred fifty years of slavery. Ninety years of Jim Crow. Sixty years of separate but equal. Thirty-five years of racist housing policy. Until we reckon with our compounding moral debts, America will never be whole.

6.title: The Minneapolis Police Officers to be charged for murder after killing innocent black man
6.subtitle: Stand up to the Minneapolis Police Department and demand that both officers are charged with murder and sentenced to the highest possible amount of time in Federal prison.

6.title: Nia the Loc God
6.subtitle: A natural oil that your hair will love. You are one step closer to moisturized, shiny, healthy hair that smells amazing.

7.title: VZN Clothing
7.subtitle: Our clothing is made to motivate you to visualize your goals and remain persistent through adversity. Vision is not simply seeing with the eyes, but rather creating a positive image and experience for your future success with your mind. By following your vision with action and remaining persistent through adversity, we believe anything is possible.

7.title: The Hate U Give
7.subtitle: Based on the best-selling novel, The Hate U Give tells the story of Starr Carter, who lives in two worlds: the poor, black neighborhood where she resides and the mostly white prep school she attends. This uneasy balance is shattered when she witnesses the fatal shooting of her childhood friend by a policeman. Facing pressures from all sides, Starr must find her voice and stand up for what’s right.

8.title: Find Your Representatives
8.subtitle: Here you can find your representatives, how to contact them, bills they’ve introduced, committees they serve on, and political contributions they’ve received.

8.title: Black Lives Matter
8.subtitle: We appreciate your support of the movement and our ongoing fight to end state-sanctioned violence, liberate Black people, and end white supremacy forever.

9.title: Justice for Julius Jones
9.subtitle: Julius Jones is on death row in Oklahoma, despite maintaining his innocence and compelling evidence that he was wrongfully convicted. Send an email to express your support of his release.

emailInfo.subject: Justice for Julius Jones
emailInfo.messageBody:
Dear Oklahoma Pardon & Parole Board members,

I strongly feel that Julius Darius Jones (# 270147) was wrongfully convicted of murder and sentenced to death in 2002. A crime for which he has always maintained his innocence.

Jones, a black 19 year old man, was arrested in 1999 for shooting white insurance executive Paul Scott Howell in Edmond, Oklahoma. At the time of his arrest, Julius was a successful athlete and honor student on scholarship at the University of Oklahoma.

Recently, new evidence of racial bias in the Jones’ case has been uncovered by the ABC documentary, “The Last Defense.”

One day after the documentary finale aired (7-25-18), the Oklahoma Criminal Court of Appeals released a document indicating they could take a look at the Jones’ case.

There are many factors that were overlooked and never presented during the Julius Jones trial.
1. Jones’ attorney during the trial was inexperienced by his own admission and this was his first death penalty case.
2. Several key pieces of evidence were never presented to the jury.
3. Tunnel vision set in and the police and prosecutor ignored evidence pointing to others as the shooter.
4. The court ignored an alleged racial statement made by one of the jurors
5. The jury judged Jones based on his race.
After viewing the recent ABC documentary, “The Last Defense,” I am even more convinced than ever of Julius’ innocence and that he should be given a new trial. I also ask that District Attorney David Prater release Julius Jones’ case files to his attorneys in order to promote public trust in both the criminal justice system and in Julius Jones’s case.

We all have all heard the phrase ‘beyond a shadow of doubt.’ To me, there is more than a shadow of doubt in this case.

Please, I ask that you do whatever is within your power to support Julius Jones’ Clemency Petition and see that this injustice – the wrongful conviction of Julius Jones – is overturned.

Thank you,
[Your Name]
[Your location]

9.title: Inn8 Apparel
9.subtitle: Your mind. Your body. Your individuality. Your imperfections. These are the things you are born with. They are innate. Embrace them. They are yours. Celebrate them. They are yours. Love them. They are you.

10.title: Learn about Julius Jones
10.subtitle: Listen to the Jason Flom & Kim Kardashian West talk about Julius Jones’ story.

10.title: Learn about Julius Jones
10.subtitle: Learn about Julius’ life and what led to his wrongful conviction through Viola Davis' docu-series "The Last Defense."

11.title: Seeing White Podcast Series
11.subtitle: Just what is going on with white people? Police shootings of unarmed African Americans. Acts of domestic terrorism by white supremacists. The renewed embrace of raw, undisguised white-identity politics. Unending racial inequity in schools, housing, criminal justice, and hiring. Some of this feels new, but in truth it’s an old story.

11.title: Justice for George Floyd
11.subtitle: Text JUSTICE to 668366 to demand every cop involved in the murder of George Floyd be charged without bail.

12.title: 1619 Podcast
12.subtitle: An audio series from The Times observing the 400th anniversary of the beginning of American slavery.

12.title: Open a random campaign to donate to
12.subtitle: Take the effort of decision out of it -- tap here and we'll select a random campaign for you to support!
12.info: Update to the latest version of the app to get access to this feature

13.title: The Costs of Racism to White People
13.subtitle: We tend to think of racism as a problem for people of color and something we should be concerned about for their sake. However, the costs of racism to white people are devastating, especially to those of us without the money and power to buffer their effects.

13.title: Accountability in a Time of Justice
13.subtitle: Accountability is a well-worn word in social justice circles. We have worked hard to figure out what accountability means to us as we attempt to walk our social justice talk.

14.title: Just Mercy: A Story of Justice and Redemption
14.subtitle: An unforgettable true story about the potential for mercy to redeem us, and a clarion call to end mass incarceration in America — from one of the most inspiring lawyers of our time.

14.title: Text a bot for book suggestions
14.subtitle: Twitter user @ecmoy created a bot that you can text for recommendations of books written by Black authors based on genre. It will also link you to a Black-owned bookstore that is selling the title. Text (409) 404-0403 to try it!

15.title: Riot Swim
15.subtitle: Riot Swim is an online designer swimwear and beachwear brand, offering an exclusive collection of bikinis, one piece swimsuits, and more.

15.title: Ava DuVernay's "13th"
15.subtitle: In this thought-provoking documentary, scholars, activists and politicians analyze the criminalization of African Americans and the U.S. prison boom.

16.title: Seven factors that contribute to American racism
16.subtitle: Of the seven factors the researchers identified, perhaps the most insidious is passivism or passive racism, which includes an apathy toward systems of racial advantage or denial that those systems even exist.

16.title: Justice For Tony McDade
16.subtitle: Tony McDade was a transgender black man who got killed by police in Tallahassee. Sign this petition and encourage others to do so as well to get his name out there.

17.title: Support our Young Protest Leaders #freetianna
17.subtitle: On Tuesday, July 21, Tianna Arata was arrested by San Luis Obispo PD at about 8 p.m. near Mitchell Park as she and other demonstrators were loading up a car after the protest had already dispersed.

17.title: Shop Thoughtful
17.subtitle: thoughtful is a nonprofit that seeks to promote black businesses and create a one-stop-shop for consumers who want to vote with their wallets. thoughtful does not take any commissions off of the businesses it promotes, it is purely a hub designed to uplift and support established Black-owned businesses online.

18.title: Email for Tianna Arata
18.subtitle: Email San Luis Obispo District Attorney Dan Dow to demand that the charges against Tianna Arata are dropped

emailInfo.subject: We demand that all charges against Tianna Arata be dropped
emailInfo.messageBody:
Hi, my name is [Your name]

I am contacting you regarding the arrest of local leader and activist Tianna Arata. Tianna is an extremely brave young person who has put her body on the line for her community, peacefully protesting throughout the past weeks against systemic racism and white supremacy. Tianna has a long history of being an activist and has always advocated for those in marginalized communities in every aspect of her life.

The SLO protests have been extremely peaceful, and the night of her arrest was no different. On July 21, after the protest was winding down, Tianna was forcefully and violently arrested by six police officers. Witnesses say she was with friends, putting their stuff back into their cars. She was charged with five counts, including two felonies, one of which was inciting a riot. All reporting on this night of protests say it was extremely peaceful.

It is obvious that the city of SLO is violently targeting this leader of the local Black Lives Matter movement in an attempt to quell resistance to racism and oppression. She has never advocated for any sort of violence in her protests, for this reason exactly. Leaders, especially young Black women, are often targeted simply for standing up for their lives and rights, and trying to better their communities. It is abhorrent that SLO is participating in this display of state violence and white supremacy. Because of this, I demand that all charges be dropped against Tianna and she be returned to her family immediately.

Tianna is innocent. I stand with her and reaffirm that her life and freedom matters, as well as the lives of all Black SLO residents. Correct your mistakes. Listen to your people. Do better.

As of Monday, August 10th, the charges against Tianna have been increased to four felony counts of false imprisonment, one count of felony conspiracy, and three misdemeanors. Tianna faces up to FIFTEEN years in prison because of these ludicrous charges. Facing these charges and possibly being convicted is leading, and will lead to, devastating repercussions for Tianna. Already, she is dealing with extreme anxiety, harassment, feeling unsafe in her own home and community, and more. Her future will be destroyed. Her dreams will be squashed. She is a leader, a student, an extremely hard worker, a beacon of joy and light, an athlete, a creative, a daughter, and most of all a person. Again, these charges will destroy Tianna's life. Drop them immediately.

Sincerely,

[Your name]

18.title: Find Black-owned bookstores near you
18.subtitle: The African American Literature Book Club (AALBC.com) has put together a map of Blac-owned bookstores across the US. Find your nearest one here.

19.title: What I am learning from my white grandchildren
19.subtitle: Are we in a post-racial society? Do we want to be? Anthony Peterson, an African American, draws from current research and from conversations with his Anglo American grandchildren to address truths about race in 21st century America.

19.title: Official Black Wall Street
19.subtitle: Get thousands of Black-owned businesses at your fingertips with the largest online platform for Black businesses.

20.title: Justice for Tianna (Donate for Legal Costs)
20.subtitle: Tianna Arata is another Black woman who was wrongfully accused and detained by exercising her right to protest. Tianna is an educated, inspirational, young woman who has been fighting for the Black community through her blood, sweat, and tears for months! She has organized many peaceful protests in the San Luis Obispo community.

20.title: Post 21
20.subtitle: Post 21 was created by a Mother-Daughter duo who wanted a comprehensive marketplace that focused on products from Black-owned businesses. They felt strongly that there’s no reason why these products are consistently being discovered when they should be household names. So, they said let’s create the place we want to shop.

21.title: Microaggressions Matter
21.subtitle: They may not always be ill-intentioned, but the slights illuminate deeper problems in America.

21.title: Email the mayor of Louisville
21.subtitle: Send a pre-filled email to Mayor Fischer of Louisville, KY to demand he holds the officers who killed Breonna Taylor accountable.

emailInfo.subject: Accountability for Breonna Taylor
emailInfo.messageBody:
Mayor Fischer,

Like thousands of people across the country, I was appalled to hear about Breonna Taylor's murder on March 13th. Echoing the requests of Louisville community organizers, the following demands must be met to ensure that the officers responsible for Breonna's death are held accountable for their brash, reprehensible actions:

  1. Your office and the Louisville City Council must address the use of force by the Louisville Metro Police
  2. The officers that killed Breonna (Sgt. Jonathan Mattingly, Detective Brett Hankison, and Detective Myles Cosgrove) must be fired, and have their pensions revoked
  3. Ensure that all necessary information is provided to a local, independent civilian community police accountability council
  4. Create policy for a transparent investigation process due to law enforcement misconduct
  5. Appoint a special prosecutor to bring forward charges against the officers and oversee all parts of this case

It is imperative that you condemn the actions of these officers. Raids cannot be performed with a shoot first, ask questions later mentality. Too many lives have been lost this way, and too often "danger" is determined by deeply entrenched racial biases, not actual threat level.

It is a tragedy that Breonna Taylor is not alive today. Police must be held to a higher standard than this. I trust that your office and the involved parties will do the right thing.

Sincerely,

[Your name] from [Your location]

22.title: How to be an Antiracist
22.subtitle: This conversation with professor Ibram X. Kendi was recorded during the 2019 Aspen Ideas Festival in Aspen, Colorado. In it, he explores what an antiracist society might look like, how we can play an active role in building it, and what being an antiracist in your own context might mean.

22.title: Donating Tip
22.subtitle: Maximize your impact by making smaller, monthly donations to a few different organizations.
22.info: Don't just let your donations be a one-time lump sum donation. Instead, spread the love out with smaller, recurring, monthly donations to continue supporting the movement beyond your first donation.

23.title: What Anti-racist Teachers Do Differently
23.subtitle: They view the success of black students as central to the success of their own teaching. Read more from Pirette McKamey, principal of San Francisco’s Mission High School and an anti-racist educator for more than 30 years.

23.title: The Collective PAC
23.subtitle: The Collective is strengthening our democracy by addressing the significant underrepresentation of the Black community in public office. We are fighting for equal representation and protection under the law so it is vital that we have Black candidates run, and Black voices heard.

24.title: Covid-19’s Impact on People in Prison
24.subtitle: People who are incarcerated are at great risk of sickness and death as a result of the Covid-19 pandemic and more must be done to release people who are imprisoned and are not a threat to public safety or are elderly or infirm.

24.title: Center for Black Equity
24.subtitle: The Center for Black Equity is the National leader in connecting members of the Black LGBTQ+ community with information and resources to educate, engage and empower their fight for equity and access.

25.title: What Happened in Kenosha, WI?
25.subtitle: Cellphone video of the incident shows police officers in Kenosha, Wisconsin shooting a Black man multiple times on August 23 as he tried to get into a vehicle. Read more about the incident and the protests that followed here.

25.title: Charge the cops who shot Jacob Blake
25.subtitle: Jacob Blake, 29, was shot by Kenosha, Wisconsin police officers in the back 7 times on August 23, 2020. Officers were on the scene due to a fight, which Jacob Blake was trying to break up. The cops who shot him need to be charged.

25.title: Justice for Jacob Blake
25.subtitle: Jacob Blake is a loving father of 6 that deserves proper medical attention and legal representation. The funds raised through this Gofundme will go toward Jacob’s medical bills, family expenses, legal representation, support for his children and therapy costs.

26.title: Justice for Jacob Blake
26.subtitle: Text Jake to 55156 to demand the immediate firing and arrest of the officer who attempted to murder him.

26.title: Support the Milwaukee Freedom Fund
26.subtitle: The Milwaukee Freedom Fund is extending support to protestors in Kenosha, WI. Their mission is to build on ongoing bail abolition efforts, support immigration efforts, work towards Black and Brown Liberation, and support Black and Brown young people as they build a new world.

27.title: What Happened in Kenosha, WI?
27.subtitle: Cellphone video of the incident shows police officers in Kenosha, Wisconsin shooting a Black man multiple times on August 23 as he tried to get into a vehicle. Read more about the incident and the protests that followed here.

27.title: Charge the cops who shot Jacob Blake
27.subtitle: Jacob Blake, 29, was shot by Kenosha, Wisconsin police officers in the back 7 times on August 23, 2020. Officers were on the scene due to a fight, which Jacob Blake was trying to break up. The cops who shot him need to be charged.

27.title: Justice for Jacob Blake
27.subtitle: Jacob Blake is a loving father of 6 that deserves proper medical attention and legal representation. The funds raised through this Gofundme will go toward Jacob’s medical bills, family expenses, legal representation, support for his children and therapy costs.

28.title: Reconstruction in America
28.subtitle: Read the Equal Justice Initiative's report on racial violence after the Civil War, from 1865-1876.

28.title: COVID-19 Voting Information
28.subtitle: As things change to help prevent the spread of COVID-19, make sure you have the latest voting information. Dates and deadlines are changing rapidly, so be sure to check with your state elections authority for the most up-to-date information.

29.title: United Negro College Fund
29.subtitle: UNCF envisions a nation where all Americans have equal access to a college education that prepares them for rich intellectual lives, competitive and fulfilling careers, engaged citizenship and service to our nation.

29.title: The RACE Method Of Talking To A Racism Skeptic
29.subtitle: The RACE Method is an approach that anti-racism allies can take to trying to share their perspective with people who are skeptical that racism against people of color is a problem worthy of specific attention. It is based on principles from non-violent communication and on findings from the science of persuasion.

30.title: American Civil Liberties Union
30.subtitle: Donate to the ACLU. The ACLU has been at the center of nearly every major civil liberties battle in the U.S. for over 100 years. This vital work depends on the support of ACLU members in all 50 states and beyond.

30.title: Register to Vote
30.subtitle: Register to vote to make your voice heard and make sure the people we elect to positions of power have the best interests of every American in mind.

31.title: Know Your Rights Camp
31.subtitle: Colin Kaepernick's organization's mission is to advance the liberation and well-being of Black and Brown communities through education, self-empowerment, mass-mobilization and the creation of new systems that elevate the next generation of change leaders.

31.title: Justice for Lakeith Smith
31.subtitle: Lakeith Smith, now 20, was charged with the murder of his friend, A’Donte Washington when he was only 15— a crime he did not commit. A'donte died at the hands of a policeman, after the police fired 4 rounds into him - and he currently walks free.
